div.l: For with þat falle he brusten hath his arme
But stonden he most vn to his own harme
For when he spake he was a noon bore doun
With hende Nicholas and Alison
Thei told euery man þat he was wode
He was a gast so of þe Noweles floode
Thorgh fantasie þat of his vanyte
He hadde I bought hym knedyng tubbes thre
And hade hem honged in the Roof a boue
And þat he preide hym for goddes loue
To sitten in þe rof ꝑper companye
The folke con laughen at his fantasye
And to þe rof þei kiken ⁊ þei cap //
And turned alle his harm to a Iape
For what so þis Carpentꝰer vnswarid
Hit was for nought no man his resoūn herd
With othes grete he was so sworn a down
That he was holden wode in alle þtat towne
For euꝰery clerc a non right held with other
Thei seid þe man is wode my leue brother
And euꝰery wight gan laugh wen at his strif
Thus swywid was þe carpntꝰers wif
For al his kepyng ⁊ his Ialousye
And absolan hath kist hir neither Eye
And Nicholas is scaldid in his toute
Þis tale is don and god saue al þe route
Here endith þe Milleris tale and

Here by gynnyth þᵉ prolog of þe
Reues tale
When folke han laughen at þis nyce cas
Of Absolon and hende Nicholas
Dyuerse folke dyuersely þei seide
But for þe more part þey lough ⁊and pleide
Ne at þis tale I saugh no man hym greue
But it were oonly Osewold þe Reue
By cause he was of carpent̉ers craft
A litel Ire is in his hert laft
